summary: beau week day 3: modern au/dairon AO3  Dairon is striding down the sidewalk, a large to-go bag on their arm. They can see the...
body:
beau week day 3: modern au/dairon

AO3

Dairon is striding down the sidewalk, a large to-go bag on their arm. They can see the painted blue of the Cobalt Soul Monastery in the distance, when a blunt force nearly knocks them over. They catch the bag, on the tips of their fingers, and look down, into the face of a young child, perhaps ten years old.

The child gasps for breath, and looks up at her fearfully. Before words can be exchanged, a man’s voice rings out. “Beauregard!”

The child- Beauregard, apparently- winces, before detaching herself from Dairon’s legs.

“Sorry,” she whispers, before scampering off. Dairon readjusts the bag, and continues on their way, putting Beauregard out of their mind.

It is seven years later, and Dairon is in one of the Monastery’s more secluded gyms. She turns, wiping sweat from her brow, and sees Zeenoth standing in the doorway, hand on the shoulder of a surly looking teenager.

“Expositor Dairon! Just who we were looking for! Beauregard, if you would leave us, please?”

The girl grumbles, and shoots Zeenoth an impressive glare, before walking over to one of the benches.

Zeenoth turns to her, and this is how she learns of the arrival of one Beauregard Lionett. She keeps one ear turned towards Zeenoth, and eyes Beauregard from the corner of her eye. Hands are bruised, she is scowling, but. There is… something, in her posture, her eyes, that reminds Dairon terribly of herself. She tunes back into Zeenoth and cuts him off.

“I will train her myself, Zeenoth. You are dismissed.”

He turns an interesting shade of violet-red, but does as she says. He really is rather irritating, regardless of good intentions.

He marches over to the girl, and Dairon watches the realization wash over her. An interesting variety of emotions- anger, apathy, interest, a flash of hope.

Dairon walks through the park, her usual route home, not expecting anything to be different. This is her first mistake. There is shouting, towards her left, and then the sound of punches being thrown. They intend to keep walking, until they hear a familiar shout- Beauregard. Dairon breaks into a run, and it doesn’t take long to understand the situation. Three boys- 18, 19 perhaps, surround her student, who is poised defensively in front of a young child. Beau fights admirably, but she is new, yet.

Dairon walks calmly up to the largest of the three, and delivers a swift kick to the back of his legs. The fight ends soon after that, although not soon enough for Beau to avoid a black eye and broken nose. Beau leans down to the child, and despite her rather gory state, they don’t flinch. She whispers something, and the child nods fiercely, before running off.

Dairon sighs, and then nods towards Beau. “Come with me,” she says, and starts walking. It takes a few seconds before Beau catches up.

“Where are we going? Am I in trouble?”

Dairon holds back a smile at the familiar question. “No, you are not in trouble. And we are going to my home.”

They walk the five minutes it takes to arrive in silence, after Beau’s initial shock. Dairon’s home is modest, and simple, but well lived in. She leads Beau to the kitchen table, and begins pulling out ice.

By the time Dairon judges Beau to be out of any immediate medical dangers, the sun has set. The Cobalt Soul is rather far, and curfew has long passed besides. Dairon thinks.

She gets up, walks to the pantry in the hall, emerges with hands full of bedding.

“You are welcome to sleep on the couch- I have no guest room.”

Beau gapes for a second, before she remembers herself. She accepts awkwardly, and when Dairon rises with the sun the next morning, she sees her student sprawled wildly, mostly on the floor. The image endears her, and she makes breakfast enough for two.

blog.name: hidden-dreamscape
blog.title: Dreamers Never Sleep
blog.description:
“Are you an idiot?”

“No, sir, I’m a dreamer.”

summary: Never Trust A Man Who Can Dance
title: Never Trust A Man Who Can Dance
body:
Pairing: Pre-Widomauk
Using @connorshero ‘s 200 dialogue prompts. 51. & 57.

Molly slid up near-silently to the corner where Caleb sat in the bar, hunched over a mug of ale with his hands wrapped tightly around it. He was staring into it like he was contemplating drowning himself in it rather than drinking it.
“Not your scene?”
Caleb jumped violently, apparently not having noticed the conspicuous purple tiefling appear next to him but didn’t flinch away. Molly made a mental note not to sneak up on the contemplative wizard again.
He made a non-committal sound in his throat. “It’s a bit loud for me I’m afraid, Mollymauk.”
“Shame, that. I was hoping to see you let loose a little.”
“I’m not sure I’d know how. I never really had an opportunity for… all that.”
Molly tilted his head to get a better look at Caleb, noting—not for the first time—the ever-present dark circles beneath his eyes and tight line of his lips. He got the sense that Caleb looked a good deal older than he actually was. There were more lines in the man’s face that he had any right to. Molly knew very little about Caleb, but it was clear to all of them that he had been through a lot, whatever it may have been. 

Inexplicably, he felt a strange sense of identity with Caleb. That was rare, for him, since his identity comprised of very little experience. They both seemed lost, in one way or another, both running from a past they’d rather not think about. Both avoiding a background they felt betrayed by, unsure whether their actions were their own fault or someone else’s. Caleb had never told him anything about his life at all, but Molly could read it in him. In his unsure gaze, in the lines of his posture. In the determined mindset but directionless soul.
“Well,” Molly began again, “Maybe you should take the opportunity now.”
Finally, Caleb looked at him. He eyed him from beneath his ginger eyelashes, his hunched shoulders heaved in a sigh before straightening up at last. “I should need to be a great deal drunker; I think.”
“Then let me buy you another drink or two.”
Caleb actually looked up at him then, tilted his head and gave a slow, rare smile. A flicker of amusement. Of endearment. “Are you trying to seduce me, Mollymauk?”
Molly held Caleb’s gaze, putting their eyes on a level. “That depends,” he said slowly, “Are you seducible?”
He scoffed, his drink shifting in his bandage wrapped hands, but he didn’t break eye contact.
A sense of triumph stirred in his chest. Caleb deserved a little bit of fun, a little bit of flirting. Just something to get him out of his own head. God knew he was stuck in there far too often. And if he was willing to participate, even better.
“That also depends,” Caleb replied, and Molly thought he saw a flicker of surprise in the blue eyes of his companion. Good. One should always aim to surprise one’s self.
“On what?”
“On how expensive those drinks are,”
“Fair enough.”
Molly chuckled—it was rare that Caleb told a joke—and took a moment to pull himself away from Caleb’s unblinking gaze. There was something a little addictive about those gradual, reluctant smiles and the intensity in those dark blue, thoughtful eyes. 

He went to the bar and ordered two of the most expensive drinks he could afford. This, of course, was what money was for.
Returning to Caleb, he was relieved to find that he had not returned to brooding over his ale but had instead drained it. Proudly, Molly presented him with the two drinks, and he gawped at him. “Molly, I know what I said, but these are a little too expensive.”
“Not at all,” he replied, dropping back into the seat beside Caleb. It pleased Molly to hear him use his nickname. He usually used his full name; it came across as something of a linguistic quirk. Molly had to admit; it was very endearing. Even more so when it was eventually foregone in favour of the nickname. It felt like progress.
“You take one. I am not such a drinker.”

Molly could not complain about the compromise as he claimed one of the deliciously expensive drinks.

It was the most comfortable silence that Molly had experienced in a long time, sitting there in the loneliest corner of this busy bar with Caleb Widogast, drinking ridiculously expensive drinks whilst Jester and Beauregard did an exuberant drunken tango around the floor space.

He watched Caleb with something akin to fascination as he worked on his drink. He was really very handsome underneath the lines and the now mostly vacant layer of grime.

Caleb didn’t seem to mind him watching.

Ah, yes. A little bit of flirting is good for the soul. Even one that is perhaps a little fractured; in need of attention.
“We should join them,” He suggested with a grin, glancing over to Jester and Beau, now laughing their heads off as they switched to the clumsiest waltz ever to exist. Caleb huffed something that was very nearly a laugh but wasn’t quite.
“I don’t think so,”
“We’ll see when you reach the bottom of that drink.”
Caleb huffed again. “I don’t exactly consider myself to be a dancer, my friend.”
Molly nearly asked what Caleb did consider himself to be but stopped himself at the last moment. He was sure the answer probably wasn’t good, considering what he knew about Caleb, and he wasn’t about to consciously bring the mood down. He wanted to distract Caleb from whatever had been watching him back as he’d stared into that mug of ale.
“You don’t know how?”
“I know how to dance,” he corrected, “I can certainly waltz better than Jester and Beau.” He nodded in their direction. It had been a mistake on Beau’s part to convince Jester to drink with her. All the windows crashed open for about the fifth time that evening.
“Oh, it’s all coming out now, Widogast.” He nudged him with an elbow, sighing dramatically, “Never trust a man who can dance.”
“I have trouble believing that you of all people don’t know how to dance.”
“And did I ever say I was trustworthy?”
Caleb really did chuckle then, and it was an awfully out of practice sound. They’d have to fix that. Soon.

They both surveyed their now empty drinks, placed next to each other on the table.

“Guess it’s time to dance, Caleb Widogast.” Molly’s grin was surely wide enough for the both of them, but Caleb was smiling again, consistently now. Reluctant, but uniquely unburdened. He stood, turning with his arm extended in a sweeping arc of invitation.
“Make me,”
“Maybe I will,” He raised a rather suggestive eyebrow.
“Prove it.”
Ha. The ultimatum. The gauntlet had been thrown.
Mollymauk Tealeaf was going to dance with Caleb Widogast if it was the last thing either of them ever did.
In one graceful swoop, Molly wrapped his arms around Caleb’s stick-thin torso and lifted him clean from the bench seat. The man made a strangled cry that wasn’t quite a protest and more like another laugh so Molly continued to lift Caleb bodily toward where the girls danced so clumsily.

The night went on. Caleb and Molly danced with laughter in their heads and hearts and with worries left behind them. They danced with flirtatious remarks and serious undertones. They danced with wandering thoughts and focused minds. They danced with joy. They danced with freedom. They danced with each other.
It felt like a release.

Molly liked the feel of Caleb’s hands in his and Caleb liked the way Molly… Well. He just liked Molly.
body_abstract:
Pairing: Pre-Widomauk
Using @connorshero ‘s 200 dialogue prompts. 51. & 57.

Molly slid up near-silently to the corner where Caleb sat in the bar, hunched over a mug of ale with his hands wrapped tightly around it. He was staring into it like he was contemplating drowning himself in it rather than drinking it.
“Not your scene?”
Caleb jumped violently, apparently not having noticed the conspicuous purple tiefling appear next to him but didn’t flinch away. Molly made a mental note not to sneak up on the contemplative wizard again.
He made a non-committal sound in his throat. “It’s a bit loud for me I’m afraid, Mollymauk.”
“Shame, that. I was hoping to see you let loose a little.”
“I’m not sure I’d know how. I never really had an opportunity for… all that.”
Molly tilted his head to get a better look at Caleb, noting—not for the first time—the ever-present dark circles beneath his eyes and tight line of his lips. He got the sense that Caleb looked a good deal older than he actually was. There were more lines in the man’s face that he had any right to. Molly knew very little about Caleb, but it was clear to all of them that he had been through a lot, whatever it may have been.

“Not your scene?”
Caleb jumped violently, apparently not having noticed the conspicuous purple tiefling appear next to him but didn’t flinch away. Molly made a mental note not to sneak up on the contemplative wizard again.
He made a non-committal sound in his throat. “It’s a bit loud for me I’m afraid, Mollymauk.”
“Shame, that. I was hoping to see you let loose a little.”
“I’m not sure I’d know how. I never really had an opportunity for… all that.”
Molly tilted his head to get a better look at Caleb, noting—not for the first time—the ever-present dark circles beneath his eyes and tight line of his lips. He got the sense that Caleb looked a good deal older than he actually was. There were more lines in the man’s face that he had any right to. Molly knew very little about Caleb, but it was clear to all of them that he had been through a lot, whatever it may have been. 

[[MORE]]

Inexplicably, he felt a strange sense of identity with Caleb. That was rare, for him, since his identity comprised of very little experience. They both seemed lost, in one way or another, both running from a past they’d rather not think about. Both avoiding a background they felt betrayed by, unsure whether their actions were their own fault or someone else’s. Caleb had never told him anything about his life at all, but Molly could read it in him. In his unsure gaze, in the lines of his posture. In the determined mindset but directionless soul.
“Well,” Molly began again, “Maybe you should take the opportunity now.”
Finally, Caleb looked at him. He eyed him from beneath his ginger eyelashes, his hunched shoulders heaved in a sigh before straightening up at last. “I should need to be a great deal drunker; I think.”
“Then let me buy you another drink or two.”
Caleb actually looked up at him then, tilted his head and gave a slow, rare smile. A flicker of amusement. Of endearment. “Are you trying to seduce me, Mollymauk?”
Molly held Caleb’s gaze, putting their eyes on a level. “That depends,” he said slowly, “Are you seducible?”
He scoffed, his drink shifting in his bandage wrapped hands, but he didn’t break eye contact.
A sense of triumph stirred in his chest. Caleb deserved a little bit of fun, a little bit of flirting. Just something to get him out of his own head. God knew he was stuck in there far too often. And if he was willing to participate, even better.
“That also depends,” Caleb replied, and Molly thought he saw a flicker of surprise in the blue eyes of his companion. Good. One should always aim to surprise one’s self.
“On what?”
“On how expensive those drinks are,”
“Fair enough.”
Molly chuckled—it was rare that Caleb told a joke—and took a moment to pull himself away from Caleb’s unblinking gaze. There was something a little addictive about those gradual, reluctant smiles and the intensity in those dark blue, thoughtful eyes. 

He went to the bar and ordered two of the most expensive drinks he could afford. This, of course, was what money was for.
Returning to Caleb, he was relieved to find that he had not returned to brooding over his ale but had instead drained it. Proudly, Molly presented him with the two drinks, and he gawped at him. “Molly, I know what I said, but these are a little too expensive.”
“Not at all,” he replied, dropping back into the seat beside Caleb. It pleased Molly to hear him use his nickname. He usually used his full name; it came across as something of a linguistic quirk. Molly had to admit; it was very endearing. Even more so when it was eventually foregone in favour of the nickname. It felt like progress.
“You take one. I am not such a drinker.”

Molly could not complain about the compromise as he claimed one of the deliciously expensive drinks.

It was the most comfortable silence that Molly had experienced in a long time, sitting there in the loneliest corner of this busy bar with Caleb Widogast, drinking ridiculously expensive drinks whilst Jester and Beauregard did an exuberant drunken tango around the floor space.

He watched Caleb with something akin to fascination as he worked on his drink. He was really very handsome underneath the lines and the now mostly vacant layer of grime.

Caleb didn’t seem to mind him watching.

Ah, yes. A little bit of flirting is good for the soul. Even one that is perhaps a little fractured; in need of attention.
“We should join them,” He suggested with a grin, glancing over to Jester and Beau, now laughing their heads off as they switched to the clumsiest waltz ever to exist. Caleb huffed something that was very nearly a laugh but wasn’t quite.
“I don’t think so,”
“We’ll see when you reach the bottom of that drink.”
Caleb huffed again. “I don’t exactly consider myself to be a dancer, my friend.”
Molly nearly asked what Caleb did consider himself to be but stopped himself at the last moment. He was sure the answer probably wasn’t good, considering what he knew about Caleb, and he wasn’t about to consciously bring the mood down. He wanted to distract Caleb from whatever had been watching him back as he’d stared into that mug of ale.
“You don’t know how?”
“I know how to dance,” he corrected, “I can certainly waltz better than Jester and Beau.” He nodded in their direction. It had been a mistake on Beau’s part to convince Jester to drink with her. All the windows crashed open for about the fifth time that evening.
“Oh, it’s all coming out now, Widogast.” He nudged him with an elbow, sighing dramatically, “Never trust a man who can dance.”
“I have trouble believing that you of all people don’t know how to dance.”
“And did I ever say I was trustworthy?”
Caleb really did chuckle then, and it was an awfully out of practice sound. They’d have to fix that. Soon.

They both surveyed their now empty drinks, placed next to each other on the table.

“Guess it’s time to dance, Caleb Widogast.” Molly’s grin was surely wide enough for the both of them, but Caleb was smiling again, consistently now. Reluctant, but uniquely unburdened. He stood, turning with his arm extended in a sweeping arc of invitation.
“Make me,”
“Maybe I will,” He raised a rather suggestive eyebrow.
“Prove it.”
Ha. The ultimatum. The gauntlet had been thrown.
Mollymauk Tealeaf was going to dance with Caleb Widogast if it was the last thing either of them ever did.
In one graceful swoop, Molly wrapped his arms around Caleb’s stick-thin torso and lifted him clean from the bench seat. The man made a strangled cry that wasn’t quite a protest and more like another laugh so Molly continued to lift Caleb bodily toward where the girls danced so clumsily.

The night went on. Caleb and Molly danced with laughter in their heads and hearts and with worries left behind them. They danced with flirtatious remarks and serious undertones. They danced with wandering thoughts and focused minds. They danced with joy. They danced with freedom. They danced with each other.
It felt like a release.

Molly liked the feel of Caleb’s hands in his and Caleb liked the way Molly… Well. He just liked Molly.

Bc everyone's favourite critical recapper deserves more love
🎲🎲🎲
Posts once a day at 8pm UK time (unless I'm very behind on CR and Talks)

blog.name: sassynightcat
blog.title: Cats, Poetry, History, RPGs, Geekery; me

summary: When you are scrolling down your dash, sees a comment about the newest Talks Machina and just sighs, logs on to twitch and...
body:
When you are scrolling down your dash, sees a comment about the newest Talks Machina and just sighs, logs on to twitch and watches it because god damn you got curious and it can’t wait.

Also, Taliesin and Ashley are golden <3
